titleStmt.title: SII 2.27: original edition by Eugen Julius Theodor Hultzsch
No. 27. IN THE INNER GOPURA, ON THE RIGHT OF THE ENTRANCE.

summary.p: This inscription records, that a minister of Rājarājadēva deposited a sum of money, the interest of which was to be spent for purchasing camphor. The deposit was made in the 28th, and the inscription itself engraved in the 29th year of the reign of Rājarājadēva.

translation.p: 1. There was engraved on stone (1) the money, which had been deposited until the twenty-ninth year (of the reign) of the lord Śrī-Rājarājadēva, to be put out to interest for the benefit of the god, by Kāṟāyil-eḍutta-Pādam, (who was a native of) Rājakēsari-nallūr in Iṅgaṇāḍu, (a subdivision) of Arumoṛidēva-vaḷanāḍu, the headman (kiṛavaṉ) of Rājakēsari-nallūr, and the royal minister who wrote the ordersSee page 109, note 5, and page 112, note 5. of the lord Śrī-Rājarājadēva, and (2) the village, which had received the deposited money on interest.

2. Fifty kāśu were deposited (under the condition) that, as long as the moon and the sun endure, an interest of one eighth kāśu per year should be paid for each kāśu, so as to realize six kāśuAs stated correctly in paragraph 3, (1/�) of 50 is 6(1/4). The inscription does not say what became of the additional (1/4) kāśu. for (purchasing),—at the rate of three kaṛañju of camphor for each kāśu,—eighteen kaṛañju of camphor per year, viz., (one) mañjāḍi of camphor per day, to be burnt instead of the wick in one perpetual sacred lampnontāviḷakku or, as it is frequently spelt in inscriptions, nantāviḷakku is perhaps a corruption of nontāviḷakku, ‘a lamp, the wick of which need not be trimmed’ (because oil is continually supplied to it). for the benefit of the god.

3. The members of the assembly of Perunaṅgai[maṅgalam], a brahmadēya in Veṇṇi-kūṟṟam, (a subdivision) of Nittaviṉōda-vaḷanāḍu, have to pay every year, as long as the moon and the sun endure, six and a quarter kāśu into the treasury of the lord for these fifty kāśu, which they have received after (the harvest of) the paśāṉ in the twenty-eighth year (of the reign) of the lord Śrī-Rājarājadēva,—the rate of interest being one eighth kāśu per year for each kāśu.
